title: 109_s993
content: Section 1 introduces a new excise tax on the acquisition of interests in insurance contracts by certain exempt organizations. This tax is imposed under Subchapter F of Chapter 42 of the Internal Revenue Code. A new excise tax is imposed on the acquisition of interests in insurance contracts by certain exempt organizations. The tax is equal to 100 percent of the acquisition costs of the interest. A taxable acquisition refers to the acquisition of any direct or indirect interest in an applicable insurance contract by an applicable exempt organization or a person not meeting certain criteria. The term 'applicable insurance contract' includes life insurance, annuity, or endowment contracts involving both exempt and non-exempt organizations. The new excise tax applies to the acquisition of interests in insurance contracts by certain exempt organizations, equal to 100 percent of acquisition costs. The term 'applicable insurance contract' includes life insurance, annuity, or endowment contracts. Exceptions exist for contracts where all parties have an insurable interest, are named beneficiaries, or have specific interests. The excise tax applies to the acquisition of interests in insurance contracts by exempt organizations, with exceptions for contracts where all parties have an insurable interest or specific interests. The sole interest of each person must be as a beneficiary of a trust or as a trustee holding an interest in the contract in a fiduciary capacity for the benefit of exempt organizations or specified persons. The excise tax applies to the acquisition of interests in insurance contracts by exempt organizations. Acquisition costs include fees, commissions, charges, or other amounts paid in connection with acquiring an interest in the contract. Timing of payments for acquisition costs is subject to specific rules. An interest in the contract encompasses any right related to the contract, whether as an owner, beneficiary, or in another capacity. An interest in an insurance contract includes any right related to the contract, whether as an owner, beneficiary, or in another capacity. An indirect interest includes an interest in an entity holding an interest in the contract. In the case of an exchange of contracts with no gain or loss, any interest in the contracts involved is treated as an interest in all contracts. Increasing an interest is considered a separate acquisition. The text discusses the taxation of acquisitions of interests in insurance contracts before they are considered applicable insurance contracts. It defines an applicable exempt organization and states that the tax imposed by this section is not considered an investment in the contract. The Secretary is authorized to create necessary regulations for implementation. The Secretary is authorized to create regulations for the taxation of acquisitions of interests in insurance contracts, including exemptions, rules for pre-acquisition interests, prevention of multiple taxes on the same interest, and avoidance of section purposes. The table of subchapters for chapter 42 of the Code is amended by adding a new item. "Subchapter F. Insurance contracts in which certain exempt organizations hold interests. Reporting Requirements. Subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section: SEC. 6050U. RETURNS RELATING TO APPLICABLE INSURANCE CONTRACTS IN WHICH CERTAIN EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS HOLD INTERESTS." The reporting requirements for exempt organizations acquiring interests in applicable insurance contracts are outlined in subsections (a) and (b). Exempt organizations and other persons acquiring taxable interests must file a return as described in subsection (c). Additionally, if an interest is transferred to other persons, each acquiring party must also make the required return. The time for filing the return is determined by the Secretary. The return filing requirements for exempt organizations acquiring interests in applicable insurance contracts are specified in subsections (a) and (b). Returns must be filed in accordance with the Secretary's timeline, including specific calendar years for acquisitions and transfers. The form and content of the returns are prescribed by the Secretary to include relevant details such as names, addresses, and taxpayer identification numbers. The return filing requirements for acquiring interests in applicable insurance contracts under section 4965 include providing specific information such as names, addresses, and taxpayer identification numbers of the parties involved. Additionally, a written statement must be furnished to individuals whose taxpayer information is included in the return. The written statement required under subsection (a) must include the name, address, and contact information of the person making the return, as well as the taxpayer identity information. Penalties for non-compliance are outlined in section 6724(d) of the Code. The text discusses amending clauses in the Code related to returns for applicable insurance contracts held by exempt organizations. The Code is being amended to include a new subparagraph related to tax payments on returns for applicable insurance contracts held by exempt organizations. The Code is amended to include reporting requirements for existing insurance contracts held by exempt organizations, effective for contracts issued after May 3, 2005. Exempt organizations must report on such contracts within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit reports on insurance contracts held by exempt organizations to the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance within 6 months of the required filing date, including any legislative recommendations.
